title: 'I prayed it was a bag': PE teacher on moment he fatally ran down pupil, 15, in school minibus
text:
'I prayed it was a bag': PE teacher on moment he fatally ran down pupil, 15, in school minibus Teacher Christopher Brooks was taking boys to an after-school rugby match when Ashley Talbot ran into the path of his vehicle, an inquest heard Share By Louie Smith 23:02, 15 FEB 2017 News Ashley Talbot, 15, died after the collision with the school minibus (Photo: Wales Online) Share A teacher has described the moment he ran over a pupil while driving a school minibus, saying he prayed it was a bag and not a person.
PE teacher Christopher Brooks was taking boys to an after-school rugby match when 15-year-old Ashley Talbot and another boy ran out into the path of his vehicle.
The Year 11 student at Maesteg Comprehensive in Bridgend, South Wales, died at the scene on December 10, 2014.
On Wednesday Mr Books’ evidence was read to the jury at Aberdare Coroner’s Court after coroner Andrew Barkley said it was not disputed.
The road near the school in Bridgend, South Wales, where the accident happened (Photo: Wales Online) Mr Brooks said he was driving down the road when he saw something “out of the corner of his eye”.
There was an “instantaneous bang” and the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, who was running with Ashley fell to the ground.
He said he heard a second louder bang and felt the minibus lift over something in the road.
“I prayed it was (the other boy’s) school bag,” he said.
“It happened so quickly. I was in the process of reacting to (the other boy) when I felt the second impact.
“I braked as hard and quickly as I could but there was not enough time ... I ran to (the other boy) who was stood holding his hip and asked if he was okay.
“He said he was all right and said, ‘Sorry sir, my fault, I was going for the bus’.”
Mr Brooks said it was then that he saw Ashley, who was lying half under the minibus and who was already being helped by others.
One of the school bus drivers, Hedley Williams, who was standing nearby, described the end of the school day as a “free-for-all”, with children walking and running across the road from between parked vehicles, as buses and cars were driven along the road in both directions.
“I always thought it was an accident waiting to happen,” he said, adding that he spoke to teachers about it.
Tributes left to tragic Ashley after the fatal accident (Photo: Wales Online) “I had the impression that I needed to keep quiet as I was only a bus driver.”
Mr Williams said there had been a similar incident the Monday before the incident when two pupils walked in front of the school minibus and were shouted at by a driver who managed to stop in time.
He said the school adopted new policies after Ashley’s death, which included extending the bus bays so they could all park on one side of the road.
The inquest heard there is also now a block on vehicle movements between 2.55pm and 3.10pm.
Police Constable Christopher Street, a forensic collision investigator, said the two boys would have been running at 6mph-10mph, while Mr Brooks was probably driving at between 14mph-17mph just before the collision.
He said the buses parked on either side of the road created a tunnel, restricting Mr Brook’s view.
A bus driver claimed the incident was "an accident waiting to happen", an inquest heard (Photo: Wales Online) He said the speed was not excessive, there was no evidence the teacher had been distracted, and added: “He would not have had a warning as to the intention of the two boys.”
Pc Street said that even if the bus had been going at 5mph at the point of impact it could still have run over Ashley due to the lack of warning Mr Brooks had.
“It is entirely possible that the front wheel may have gone over the casualty even at such a low speed,” he said.
Ashley, a budding mechanic and motocross fan from, was described as popular and well-loved by his classmates after his death.
The inquest continues.
